keyTakeAways: A massive fire at Dhaka’s Hazrat Shahjalal International Airport cargo complex destroyed critical inventory, including raw materials, garments, and product samples, threatening exports.
Estimated losses could reach up to $1 billion, severely impacting Bangladesh’s garment exporters and the global supply chain.
Product samples are vital for securing new buyers and expanding orders; their loss may jeopardize future business in the garment sector.
Bangladesh is the world’s second-largest apparel exporter after China, supplying major retailers like Walmart, H&M, and the Gap.
The incident is part of a series of fires in Bangladesh this week, raising concerns about safety and potential sabotage.
The airport cargo village handles over 600 metric tons of dry cargo daily, with volume doubling during peak export season.
The government is investigating the fire, with a warning that any evidence of sabotage or arson will be met with a strong response.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A massive fire at the cargo complex of Dhaka’s Hazrat Shahjalal International Airport has devastated Bangladesh’s garment export industry, destroying raw materials, finished garments, and critical product samples. The Bangladesh Garment Manufacturers and Exporters Association (BGMEA) estimates losses could reach $1 billion, with significant disruption to global supply chains that serve major retailers like Walmart, H&M, and The Gap. The incident occurs during the peak export season, when logistics demand is highest, and is part of a series of fires in Bangladesh this week, raising concerns about industrial safety and potential sabotage. The loss of product samples threatens future business expansion, while the airport’s role as a key logistics hub amplifies the impact. The government is investigating the cause and has warned of swift action against any acts of arson or criminality.
title: Bangladesh garment exporters fear $1bn losses after huge airport fire
